title: 107_hr2874
content: The Act titled the "Debbie Smith Act" authorizes grants for training in handling sexual assault cases. The Attorney General can grant funds to states for sexual assault nurse examiner programs, training for law enforcement and first responders in handling sexual assault cases, and DNA sample collection. States must apply and comply with quality assurance standards for sample processing. Funds from this section must not replace State funds but increase the overall amount available. States can only use up to 3% of the funds for administrative costs. States receiving grants must report activities and their effectiveness to the Attorney General. The Attorney General requires states to report on grant activities and their effectiveness, including the aggregate amount of grants to each state and a summary of information provided. States must keep expenditure records for audits as required by the Attorney General. The Attorney General requires states to report on grant activities and their effectiveness, including the aggregate amount of grants to each state. States must keep expenditure records for audits related to grant funds received. States receiving grants must provide access to records for audit and examination purposes. Authorization of appropriations for grants under this section is specified for fiscal years 2002, 2003, and 2004. SEC. 3. QUALITY ASSURANCE STANDARDS FOR FORENSIC EVIDENCE COLLECTION KITS. Section 210303 of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 is amended to include standards for testing, collecting, and processing DNA samples for forensic evidence. The Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 is amended to include standards for collecting and processing DNA samples for forensic evidence, specifically for DNA analysis. Authorization of grants for DNA analysis of crime scene samples is provided under Section 4. The Attorney General may authorize grants to eligible States for DNA analysis of crime scene samples to be included in the Combined DNA Index System. States must submit an application ensuring a plan for timely DNA analysis within 10 days of sample collection. The Attorney General authorizes grants to States for DNA analysis of crime scene samples to be included in the Combined DNA Index System. Funds must not supplant State funds and are restricted to 3% for administrative costs. States receiving grants must submit reports to the Attorney General. States receiving grants under this section must submit annual reports to the Attorney General detailing activities, assessing needs met, and providing required information. The Attorney General must also submit a report to Congress within 90 days after each fiscal year, including the total grants awarded to each State and a summary of information provided by grant recipients. Each State receiving grants under this section must maintain expenditure records as required by the Attorney General for audit purposes. The definition of "State" includes various regions, and appropriations are authorized for grants under subsection (a). The Attorney General is allocated $100,000,000 for fiscal year 2002, $50,000,000 for fiscal year 2003, and $50,000,000 for fiscal year 2004 for grants under subsection (a).
